title: How to write a good essay in 40 minutes during the exam - Quora

response.answer_text: Take the first five minutes and don’t write the essay. Plan. Decide what your thesis is. Choose your supporting arguments. Jot them down. and make sure the order has a logical flow to it. (That can be “putting my best argument first/last” if you want…just don’t make the order random.) I’m NOT talking about whole sentences or a first draft of anything….just make yourself jot down the ideas in order, as a way of verifying you have actually ideas before you start writing. Because…If in that time you find you can’t come up with three supporting paragraphs, or don’t know how to support the thesis, you’ll find out in the first two minutes, not after half an hour of wasted time committed to an essay that’s doomed from the getgo. Try another thesis. If you are asked to argue for or against something, the opposite argument may be easier to write about than the one you actually believe. Sometimes you don’t figure that out until you have to decide what your argument is. This serves three purposes: 1) Ensures that your introductory paragraph will be a good one. Most people write an introduction based on their initial idea, and then, as the paper develops, get a better sense of what they are trying to say. They may craft a good conclusion to wrap it all up, but the start of the essay is still weak. This way you have thought out what your arguments are and how they tie together before you craft those few vital first sentences. 2) Helps you choose a thesis and supporting arguments that you can write a lot about. Sooo many people start an essay and then discover halfway through they don’t have enough to say. They start adding fluff for length. Better to dump your idea in the first five minutes and switch to something else than waste a half hour on sub-standard writing. 3) Organizes your essay so it is easier to write. And less likely to get off track. Five minutes seem like a long time to sacrifice? Well, this is actually the standard advice from the old SAT test, for which the essay was 25 minutes total. Even in that short a time, the benefit of taking a few minutes to plan meant the finished product was longer and better. And if this is for the SAT, or any standardized college entrance test…length matters. It shouldn’t, but it does. A recent study of SAT essays found a direct correlation between essay length and grade. The best way to manage that is to pick a subject to write about where you have a lot to say.

Understand and outline your answer first. I did this by writing 5 lines in the blue book opposite where I’m going to compose the answer. Thesis and 3 points.Topic sentence for point 1Topic sentence for point 2Topic sentence for point 3ConclusionExample: Politician X is a doodoo head because he lies, is inconsistent and prejudiced.There are many examples of politician X’s consistent lying such as this case, that case, and these other examples.We want our leadership to be rational and well considered, which politician X represents poorly.Citizens hope they are led by figures who make decisions free from bias, and it is disappointing when this is a weakness of an authority figure.Because of his constant lies, inconsistency, prejudice, politician X is a less-that-stellar leader.With these salient points in place, you just connect the dots (provide support) for your ideas. In summary, tell us what you are going to talk about, talk about it, then tell us what we talked about. By distilling your answer down like this you can make the most efficient use of your time. If you get crammed to complete … if you just provide your thesis and supporting arguments, most professors will give you at least partial credit.

Get more experience in PLANNING essays. A lot of people zero in on the writing aspect of essay-writing — which is important, of course — but they also neglect the very important aspect of building up experience in planning essays. This neglect is also a neglect of the modern schooling attitudes in many, many countries. In my schooldays over 40 years ago, we had essay homework that DIDN’T require the written-up essay. The homework required us to produce the plans and outlines for various types of essays and topics. Over time, that helped us to develop skills in planning for extended writing — and then helping us to internalise those skills so that we could develop quick MENTAL plans for writing under pressure (such as in exams). So to write a good essay under a time limit is first to build up experience in planning essays.

Memorise facts. A lot of facts. The more bricks you have, the more types of structures you can build. Read relevant articles. See what others say about the subject. How they use facts, how they construct arguments. Learn from the master. Learn to plan well. An essay well-planned is likely an essay well-written. Planning is much, much more difficult than writing. Practice speed writing. Let’s be real. Your writing speed affects how much you can write. Boost that up. Brainstorm possible questions on the topic. That shouldn’t be too hard. Then think of how you approach the questions. Time-constrained essay writing is tough, but there are of course ways to prepare for it.

A week or two before the exam, get together with three or four of your smartest classmates. Your task: to figure out the likeliest subjects of the essay questions on the final exam. Come up with no more than three subjects. Next, write the three essays, using all of the books and other material at your command. Then, reduce the essays to outlines and memorize the outlines. On exam day, you will find that your professors has chosen one of the three essay questions you and your friends predicted. Now, expand the outline you have memorized and write the essay. You will get an A+ on your test (assuming your short answers are right) and your professor will smile at you when he returns the graded essays. This is what I did in college. Works like a charm. Oh yes, in world history, the night before the final, I made a list of 100 important dates and “flash memorized them” — that is, absorbed them into short-term memory, memory not intended to last more than 24 hours. When taking the final and writing the essay, sprinkle these dates into your work like salt.

Read a lot.Keep a swap file of good articles, and go back and study why they are good.Apply what you have learned from your analysis of good articles by writing your own articles, and have several people whose expertise you respect critique them.Quora is an excellent place to collect good answers since they are limited in length, and there are plenty of people who will critique your answers (or attempts at answers), and if they are impressed, will vote them up.

You have to prepare for the essay exam beforehand if you want to get high grades and complete the examination successfully. The essay writing part is necessary and you must be sure that you can write effective content within the provided period of time. So the first thing you should do is to find what topics you can receive during the examination and try to write and proofread it within a definite time. Also, you can look through the website of the expert services to get some samples of the professionally written essays. It will be good to visit these websites to learn how to write an effective essay: Guidelines and Writing an Essay.  Here are some useful tips that can help you to prepare for this part of your examination: Try to read a lot of information using different books, newspapers, articles and blog posts related to your field and subject;Review the already written articles by other students or independent authors that are relevant to your field of study;Practice your speed writing. You must have enough time to analyze, write and proofread the paper within the given time;Learn how to plan each step and express it on your paper.

Always ensure you don’t go out of topic, to do this, keep referring to the question as you write.Grammar; Ensure you have at least 5 mins for proof reading.Stick to the point; be relevant, be simple, be direct to the point. You could seek further assistance here
